title: The Tree of Inspiration
sub_title: Finding the Extraordinary in the Ordinary
devotional:
Old Mr. Abernathy had a peculiar habit. Every morning, rain or shine, he’d sit on his porch swing, a worn-out notebook in his lap, and stare intently at the old oak tree in his front yard. Children often giggled as they passed, whispering about the “crazy tree-man.” But Sarah, a young aspiring writer, was different. She saw something intriguing in his ritual. One day, gathering her courage, she approached him.

“Mr. Abernathy,” she began, “I’ve noticed you watching that tree every day. What are you looking for?”

He smiled, a network of wrinkles crinkling around his kind eyes. “Inspiration, child,” he rasped, his voice like rustling leaves. “This old oak, she’s seen a lot. She’s weathered countless storms, provided shelter to generations of birds, and stood tall even when the world around her changes. She reminds me that even in the face of adversity, there's always beauty and resilience to be found. I write about that.” He gestured to his notebook, filled with scribbled observations and sketches.

Sarah realized that Mr. Abernathy wasn’t crazy. He was simply a keen observer, drawing inspiration from the everyday wonders of God’s creation. He found the extraordinary in the ordinary, a lesson Sarah took to heart. She began to see the world with new eyes, finding stories in the smallest of details: the way sunlight danced on the dew-covered grass, the intricate patterns of a spider’s web, the cheerful melody of a robin’s song. Summer is a good time to go on inspirational journeys.

Just as Mr. Abernathy found inspiration in the oak tree, we can find it in the scriptures. The Bible is filled with stories of faith, courage, and perseverance that can inspire us to live more fully and purposefully. We are also called to be inspirational to other people and inspire them to do good deeds. Today, let us be like Mr. Abernathy, opening our eyes to the beauty and inspiration that surrounds us, remembering that God's presence is woven into every aspect of His creation. Let us also share what we've learned with others.
image_description: An old oak tree with sunlight filtering through its leaves, casting dappled shadows on the ground.
insights: The Psalmist frequently looked to nature for inspiration and understanding of God's character. Psalm 19:1 states, 'The heavens declare the glory of God; the skies proclaim the work of his hands' (NIV). This emphasizes the idea that God's creation is a source of revelation and inspiration, offering glimpses into His power, wisdom, and beauty. Similarly, Romans 1:20 tells us that God's invisible qualities – his eternal power and divine nature – have been clearly seen, being understood from what has been made, so that people are without excuse.
prayer: Heavenly Father, open my eyes to the beauty and inspiration that surrounds me. Help me to see Your presence in the everyday wonders of Your creation. Fill my heart with courage, perseverance, and faith, so that I may live more fully and purposefully. Guide me to be a source of inspiration to others, and help me to share the lessons I learn with those around me. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: Where do you typically find inspiration? What steps can you take to be more open to the inspiration that surrounds you? How can you be a source of inspiration to others?
